LiBH 4 was studied as an SSE in several SSBs
28 using TiS 2
29 or sulfur
30 as cathode materials. These SSBs operate at a temperature of about 120 °C, allowing a sufficiently high Li-ion conductivity due to the presence of the hexagonal polymorph of LiBH 4. The working potential of both TiS 2 and S is about 2 V versus Li +/Li,
29, 30 close to the electrochemical stability window of LiBH 4, which is one of the factors explaining the progressive capacity fading. In order to decrease the SSB-operating temperature, Unemoto et al.( 31) used a LiBH 4–P 2S 5 mixture as the SSE, while Das et al.( 32) reported an SSB working at 55 °C using LiBH 4 nanoconfined in silica (MCM-41) as the SSE.
